description:
Silurus meridionalis, also known as the Southern Catfish, is a species of freshwater fish belonging to the family Siluridae. It is native to the southern regions of Europe, primarily found in the Balkans and the Iberian Peninsula.

The Southern Catfish is a bottom-dwelling species that can grow up to approximately 100 cm in length. It has a robust, elongated body with a large, flattened head and a wide, terminal mouth equipped with four pairs of long, sensitive barbels. Its coloration is typically dark brown or grayish on the upper parts of the body, transitioning to a lighter, yellowish-white underside.

This species is adapted to inhabit slow-moving or stagnant freshwater bodies, such as lakes, rivers, and swamps. It plays an important ecological role as a predator, feeding on a variety of prey, including small fish, crustaceans, and aquatic insects. The Southern Catfish is also a valued species for recreational and commercial fishing in its native range.

Conservation efforts for Silurus meridionalis are ongoing, as the species is threatened by habitat degradation, pollution, and the introduction of non-native fish species in some areas. Ongoing research and management strategies aim to ensure the long-term survival and sustainable use of this unique freshwater fish species.
